channel.title: Rite Of Passage
channel.description:
[center] Richard Wright the author of the novella, Rite Of Passage, develops Johnny Gibbs very well by
using characterizations well to make Johnny seem real. One example is when Johnny gets to go to a movie with
his best friend and is also happy because he achieved good grades. Most students reach for high grades, so
when they see they’ve somehow reached it, they feel happy. This makes Johnny Gibb seem real in the
education world.
Johnny Gibbs being a fifteen year old with good grades dresses very neatly. I can infer that he
does this because he has great parents and siblings and they influence him to do well, so he does well. This
makes Johnny Gibbs seem real in society’s viewpoint of appearance.
Connecting back to Johnny getting good grades, it’s no surprise that he can speak fluent English. Also,
the influences he gets effects how he speaks, the people around him seem to speak fluent English, which
makes him speak like that too. This makes Johnny Gibbs seem real in the language world because of his
surroundings.
Johnny Gibbs acts very calm when it comes to important things. For example, the fight with Baldy, he
pulled out all his courage and strength and fought him. Also, when the cop questioned him, he acted calm and
innocent. He probably does this because his life’s course depended on this. This makes Johnny seem real in his
behavior and actions.
When Johnny’s mom tries to protect him from the truth about him, he overreacts because he doesn’t try
to understand her feelings. This is very normal because he is a fifteen year old and he doesn’t have the
experiences to think things through clearly. This makes Johnny seem real because of his reactions to other
characters.
Johnny’s environment makes him act like a good kid because he has no negative situations where he
goes astray. This makes Johnny seem real because environment is a big factor on someone’s personality. [/center]

item.title: Rite Of Passage
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Richard Wright, the author of the novella, [u]Rite Of Passage[/u], develops Johnny Gibbs effectively through characterization to form this immensely complex and three-dimensional persona. When Johnny goes to the movies, the reader can easily relate to his situation, as the average reader enjoys watching a intense movie. Another example is a time when Johnny attained good grades, a rush of accomplishment that every student can empathize with. These events truly strengthen Johnny Gibbs as a character. Johnny is a crisply dressed fifteen year old with good grades. The reader can infer that his cultured upbringing through his supportive parents and encouraging siblings had a profound effect on his growth. Through their positive influence, he naturally becomes the teenager that he is. This facet of his life brings Johnny to life from a societal and appearance perspective. In light of his stellar school work, it is not surprising that he is well-versed in the English language. Again, those around him influence him in a positive manner. His family and friends speak exquisitely, allowing him to speak in a keen manner. Because of this language, Wright truly allows the reader to see Johnny as a multifaceted character. Another notable aspect of Johnny is his poise and composure. Grace under pressure is a valuable asset, and Johnny is extremely graceful under pressure. As he fights Baldy, he is able to draw from his reserves of courage and strength in the tussle. In answering the police officer’s questions, Johnny is still reserved, keeping his cool. This allows the reader to truly embrace Johnny as a sympathetic, complex character.

I rewrote the first four paragraphs for you. Now I’m tired.

Read full topic

item.title: Rite Of Passage
item.dc:creator: @Silver_Lining Silver Lining
item.description:
@Silver_Lining wrote:

[center]


I




want




to castrate




you.




For the sake




of humanity




please commit




seppuku




immediately.


:)[/center]
